Ok. Test-first doesn't necessarily make clear what the better solution 
is.  There is no substitute for experience.  But it does make me feel the 
pain of overly coupled, hard-to-test code that causes me to go look for a 
better solution.

As I have improved my test-first skills, I have learned to use that pain as 
a signal.  Why does testing this code hurt so much?  It could be because 
I'm stupid and need a coffee break, but it's probably because my code has a 
problem and I need to find a better way.  I think about it for a bit, and 
if I don't come up with a solution, I hunt around for ideas in a book 
written by someone who knows more than I do, or I ask a list with a lot of 
people on it who know more than I do.  I learn something and the pain goes 
away.  Now I have some new techniques for eliminating "file-angst".

Thanks for all of the great feedback :-)

At 06:50 PM 5/1/2002 -0700, you wrote:
> > Notice, everyone, how the test tool suggested a change that makes this
> > class more generally useful. Hmmmm.
>
>Well, not exactly: One solution ("a directory full of a bunch of xml
>catalog file variations becomes more readable and understandable than a
>bunch of code.") didn't require any change to the code and is seen as a
>better solution.  The tool's suggestion was I think not that obvious.
>
>If it was so obvious, why did David take the time to ask the question to
>the group?
>
>I think that you still need some experience to smell the refactoring.
>
>-Vladimir
>
